awd_titl_txt: Engineering Future Scholars: Increasing Engineering Success through a Self-Efficacy Network and Identity Development
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, this project will support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at Arizona State University's Ira A. Fulton Schools of Engineering. Throughout its five years, this project will fund 40 scholarships for students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in engineering. Scholars will be mentored by their peers, faculty, and industry professionals; conduct undergraduate research; participate in design-build-implement innovation challenges; participate in career development; and complete engineering workforce preparation experiences.

This project will follow 40 Engineering Futures Scholars for four years allowing for a longitudinal study of engineering identity development. A cohort of 20 students will be added in project year one and year two. Each cohort will be supported for four years. The scholars' future potential selves will be nurtured to facilitate engineering identity development, which is expected to support sustained motivation and persistence in their goals towards engineering degree completion. Participants will enroll in a required Build Your Engineering Future course each semester of their degree program. This course will be used to anchor identity development activities. Scholars' engineering self-efficacy and their engineering identity will be studied longitudinally using qualitative and quantitative methods, to understand the degree to which students have explored and committed to becoming an engineer while also valuing the personal and social relevance of their aspirations. A comparison group will be used to study the impact of project activities. Results of this project may strengthen the understanding of existing strategies or reveal new ones to increase undergraduate student retention in engineering and four-year graduation rates in Arizona and across the nation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF DUE Project (Award #1834166, 10/1/2018-09/30/2024), Engineering Futures Scholars: Increasing Engineering Success through a Self-Efficacy Network and Identity Development, aimed to support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at Arizona State University’s Ira A. Fulton Schools of Engineering. Throughout this project 72 students pursuing bachelor’s degrees in engineering were provided with scholarships of up to $5,000/year to fill unmet financial need after ASU financial aid packaging was completed. Scholarships worth $732,360 were distributed to academically talented, low income students.

 

Intellectual Merit

The project aimed to increase our learnings about how cohort-based efforts can better support academically talented students with high financial need to persist and succeed in developing their future “selves” as engineers. This project has resulted in institutionalized strategies for the recruitment, retention, and capacity to influence persistence of academically talented students who may be financially constrained to pursue engineering. The novelty of the approach is that it is a longitudinal study—from entry as first-time, full-time freshmen to completion of their undergraduate engineering degree—of student self-efficacy and engineering identity development, an approach that is expected to yield insights and guidance for future implementation at other institutions. Moreover, the program was uniquely structured as a cohort-based model targeting academically talented students with unmet financial need, all within a major public research university. Project strategies have informed ways to increase undergraduate student retention in engineering and four-year graduation rates in Arizona and across the nation.

 

Broader Impacts

The project supported 72 students. Their demographics are: 25% (19) female, 74% (53) male with 53% (38) identified as first-generation-to-university students. Retention in engineering is a significant challenge across the nation, with some estimates noting that 50% change out of their engineering major or drop out before graduation, and half of these do so during the first-year of college. Of the 72 students, we were been able to retain 100% (all 72 students) beyond their first-year into their second year of engineering. 94% (68 of 72) students persisted beyond their second year. 60% (43 of 72) students have completed their bachelor’s degree in engineering; 35 of whom have started work in industry, 6 started a graduate degree, and 2 have founded a start-up while also working their graduate degree. Graduates are employed in organizations such as Abbott Labs, Amazon, Arizona Public Service, ASML, Charles Schwab, DHL, Garmin, Honeywell, Intel, NXP, PayPal, Pepsico, Puget Sound Naval Shipyard, Raytheon, Rockwell Automation, State Farm, Visa, West Pharmaceutical Services. And 1% (1 of 72) students transferred to business at the end of their second year and graduated with a business degree. Only 6% (4 of 72) students left the university without completing their bachelor’s degree and these students left engineering during their second year. 33% (24 of 72) students continue to be enrolled in engineering. 15% (11 of 72) are on track to graduate in May 2025 and 18% (13 of 72) are on track to graduate in May 2026. With due attention to helping students navigate their engineering degree during their first year we have been able to increase students’ knowledge of college life and academic expectations and also improve their knowledge of engineering as field of study and career. This “navigational support” along with persistent annual financial support to fill unmet need has been an important factor in increasing retention of academically talented, low-income students in engineering. Mentoring provided by near-peers, career coaches, academic advising staff, faculty, alumni and industry representatives throughout their degree program helped these students develop a strong self-efficacy network. As students demonstrated greater affinity to engineering by “doing engineering” through undergraduate research experiences, hackathons, internships, and service learning by providing solutions to non-profit clients through a co-curricular experience, they developed their engineering identity of “being an engineer”. These strategies have helped us increase student persistence to graduation with an engineering degree


Last Modified: 01/28/2025
Modified by: Tirupalavanam G Ganesh
